chunks.en: My wife was tricked by a fake Google Chrome website and got a trojan on her computer.

chunks.zh: å‰å¤©è€å©†åœ¨ Bing æœç´¢ Chrome ä¸‹è½½ï¼Œæ’åç¬¬ä¸€çš„é“¾æ¥æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ª https://google-chrom.cn ï¼Œå¥¹è§‰å¾—æ¯”è¾ƒæ­£è§„å°±åœ¨è¿™ä¸ªç½‘ç«™ä¸Šä¸‹è½½å®‰è£…â€œChromeâ€œæµè§ˆå™¨ï¼ˆæ­¤ç½‘ç«™ä¸ç”¨ç§‘å­¦ä¸Šç½‘å°±èƒ½æ‰“å¼€ï¼‰ã€‚
chunks.en: The day before yesterday, my wife searched for Chrome downloads on Bing. The top-ranked link was https://google-chrom.cn. She thought it looked legitimate, so she downloaded and installed the 'Chrome' browser from this website (this website can be opened without using a VPN).

After installing it, Huorong (anti-virus software) on the computer popped up a warning about a trojan after a while. I used a system restore point to revert and changed passwords for Bitwarden, etc. So far, I haven't seen any losses.
As of February 21, 2025, this website can still be opened and is ranked first in Bing's Chinese search results.
https://i.imgur.com/iNs1Ls8.png
The website has been submitted to CloudFlare for abuse reporting.
Added to the PCDN download list.
Why is nobody scolding Bing?

chunks.en: @FabricPath #5 https://www.google-chrom.cn/help/24.html The link chrome.googlenav.cn in the upper right corner doesn't seem to have a CDN. I configured 42.202.173.132 www.google-chrom.cn in my local hosts file. When I visit www.google-chrom.cn again, there's a security warning, but I can still access images and other resources. So I think the IP of chrome.googlenav.cn is likely the origin server.

chunks.en: @yvkino The Edge browser on the right side of your picture shows a Cloudflare warning because a V2EX user submitted an abuse report to Cloudflare just now, which means Edge didn't block it.
It's a black market group that specializes in imitation. If it's not ransomware, it's not too bad. https://x.threatbook.com/v5/article?threatInfoID=146629
@yulgang Its origin server bandwidth is strangely high; it can't be fully utilized.

chunks.en: I'm careful when I come to V2EX. I see people using free VPNs to make wild claims on X, and there are people doing things like this with .cn domains. Aren't they afraid?

chunks.en: Coincidentally, I had the same situation recently. I searched on Bing and downloaded Chrome, and it got infected. Hilariously, it renamed my other browsers to 'Deleted Application'. And this fake Chrome couldn't be uninstalled; even 360 couldn't do anything about it. I had to reinstall the system in the end.

Scroll to the bottom: The software provided on this site is for personal learning and testing purposes only. Please delete it within 24 hours after downloading; it must not be used for any commercial purposes, otherwise the consequences will be borne by yourself. (Note: This site is not an official website!) XML
? I get a warning when I open it. What browser are you using?
https://google.cn/chrome/ can be opened directly.
@FabricPath It's Cloudflare, so I won't bother.

chunks.en: @billbob I have a MacBook Pro, the latest version of the system, and the browser is Safari. My wife has a Windows 11 laptop, the latest version of Edge.
https://google.cn/chrome/ can be opened without a VPN.
When I open it in Chrome, the entire page turns red.

chunks.en: @xdeng I don't get any warnings in Safari or Edge here. Chrome warns of a dangerous website. @mizuki9 She doesn't have much awareness of information security and trusts Bing's search rankings too much.
